mdRecord.dcterms:description: built on the site of the medieval Wilton Abbey. Following the dissolution of the monasteries, Henry VIII presented Wilton Abbey and its attached estates to William Herbert, 1st Earl of Pembroke. Herbert built Wilton House, probably on the same site as the abbey, between 1544 and 1563. South wing by Isaac de Caus and Inigo Jones, 1630s; damaged by fire 1647. Rebuilt by John Webb, probably advised by Jones. James Wyatt employed 1801-1812 by the 11th Earl to modernize the house and create more space for pictures and sculptures. Wyatt’s changes in Gothic Revival style included new hall and staircase and the cloister around the inner courtyard. Final touches were executed by Wyatt's nephew Sir Jeffry Wyatville. — https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilton_House [work]
